questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>23</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: First, solve for <math><mi>x</mi></math>. Add 9 to both sides: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. The question asks for the value of <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, so multiply 8 by 2 to get 16.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check what the question is asking for. If it asks for <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, do not stop after finding <math><mi>x</mi></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='80' x2='350' y2='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='360' y='85' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>k</text><line x1='50' y1='220' x2='350' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='360' y='225' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>m</text><line x1='260' y1='40' x2='140' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 238 80 L 210 80 A 30 30 0 0 0 226 102' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='195' y='105' font-size='14'>x°</text><path d='M 162 220 L 134 220 A 30 30 0 0 1 154 195' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='120' y='205' font-size='14'>130°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two parallel horizontal lines, k and m, intersected by a transversal line slanting from top-right to bottom-left. The interior angle on the left side of the transversal at the top line is labeled x°. The consecutive interior angle on the same side (left) at the bottom line is labeled 130°.
questions.question: In the figure, line <math><mi>k</mi></math> is parallel to line <math><mi>m</mi></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since lines <math><mi>k</mi></math> and <math><mi>m</mi></math> are parallel, consecutive interior angles (angles on the same side of the transversal and between the parallel lines) are supplementary. Therefore, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>130</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Solving for <math><mi>x</mi></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='80' x2='350' y2='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='220' x2='350' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='260' y1='40' x2='140' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 190 80 L 238 80 L 162 220 L 120 220' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' stroke-opacity='0.5'/><text x='150' y='150' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>Sum = 180°</text><text x='195' y='105' font-size='14'>x°</text><text x='120' y='205' font-size='14'>130°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart highlights the 'C' shape formed by the consecutive interior angles on the left side of the transversal, emphasizing that these two angles (130° and x°) must sum to 180°.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that for parallel lines, consecutive interior angles sum to 180 degrees, while alternate interior angles are equal.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A machine produces 150 widgets every 10 minutes. At this rate, how many widgets does the machine produce in 1 hour?
questions.explanation: First, find the rate per minute: <math><mfrac><mn>150</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> widgets per minute. Since there are 60 minutes in 1 hour, multiply the rate by 60: <math><mn>15</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>900</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Ensure units match before calculating. Convert hours to minutes if the rate is given in minutes.

questions.question: Which value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> is a solution to the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>></mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> from both sides: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>></mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Add 2 to both sides: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>></mo><mi>x</mi></math>, or <math><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Of the options provided, only -4 is less than -3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When multiplying or dividing an inequality by a negative number, remember to flip the inequality sign.

questions.question: What is the sum of the solutions to the given equation? <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>35</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>
questions.explanation: For a quadratic equation in the form <math><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the sum of the solutions is <math><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mfrac></math>. Here, <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Thus, the sum is <math><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow><mn>1</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Alternatively, factor the equation as <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, giving solutions 5 and 7, which sum to 12.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the relationship between coefficients and roots: sum = <math><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>a</mi></math> and product = <math><mi>c</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>a</mi></math>.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: From the second equation, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Substitute this into the first equation: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>. Simplifying gives <math><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>, so <math><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>, meaning <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. The value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math> is <math><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Substitution is often faster when one variable has a coefficient of 1 or -1.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,200 110,200 80,120' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='40' y='215' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='115' y='215' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='75' y='110' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='50' y='160' font-size='12' fill='black'>8</text><text x='40' y='240' font-size='12' fill='blue'>Perimeter = 24</text><polygon points='200,200 290,200 245,80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='190' y='215' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>D</text><text x='295' y='215' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>E</text><text x='240' y='70' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>F</text><text x='205' y='140' font-size='12' fill='black'>12</text><text x='200' y='240' font-size='12' fill='blue'>Perimeter = ?</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two similar triangles side-by-side. The smaller triangle ABC has side AC labeled 8 and a perimeter of 24. The larger triangle DEF has the corresponding side DF labeled 12.
questions.question: Triangles <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mi>F</mi></math> are similar, where <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> corresponds to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math> corresponds to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>E</mi></math>. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, and the perimeter of triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is 24, what is the perimeter of triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mi>F</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since the triangles are similar, the ratio of their corresponding sides determines the scale factor. The ratio of side <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>F</mi></math> to side <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math>. The perimeter of the similar triangle scales by the same factor. Therefore, the perimeter of triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mi>F</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>24</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,200 110,200 80,120' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='200,200 290,200 245,80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='0' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='red' /></marker></defs><line x1='120' y1='150' x2='180' y2='150' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><text x='130' y='140' font-size='12' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>x 1.5</text><text x='40' y='215' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='75' y='110' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='190' y='215' font-family='serif'>D</text><text x='240' y='70' font-family='serif'>F</text><text x='50' y='160' font-size='12'>8</text><text x='205' y='140' font-size='12'>12</text><text x='40' y='240' font-size='12' fill='blue'>P = 24</text><text x='200' y='240' font-size='12' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>P = 24 x 1.5 = 36</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart illustrates the scaling process. A red arrow indicates the transformation from triangle ABC to DEF with a scale factor of 1.5. The calculation for the new perimeter (24 * 1.5 = 36) is explicitly shown.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For similar triangles, the ratio of perimeters is equal to the ratio of corresponding side lengths (the scale factor) [Image of similar triangles ratio].

questions.question: A table shows the distribution of 50 students in a band class by instrument and grade level. There are 20 juniors and 30 seniors. Among the juniors, 8 play the flute. Among the seniors, 12 play the flute. If a flute player is selected at random, what is the probability that the student is a senior?
questions.explanation: First, calculate the total number of flute players: <math><mn>8</mn><mo>(</mo><mtext>juniors</mtext><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>(</mo><mtext>seniors</mtext><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. The condition is 'if a flute player is selected', so the sample space is restricted to these 20 students. The number of seniors in this group is 12. The probability is <math><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.60</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay close attention to the 'given' condition in probability problems; it defines the denominator.

questions.question: For all positive values of <math><mi>x</mi></math>, the expression <math><mfrac><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> is equivalent to <math><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></math>, where <math><mi>k</mi></math> and <math><mi>n</mi></math> are constants. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>n</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Simplify the numerator: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>8</mn></msup></math>. Divide by the denominator: <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>9</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>8</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>6</mn></msup></math>. Here, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. The value of <math><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>n</mi></math> is <math><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply exponent rules carefully: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>a</mi></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>b</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></msup></math> and <math><mfrac><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>a</mi></msup><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>b</mi></msup></mfrac><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></msup></math>.

questions.question: A landscaping company charges a flat fee of $50 for a consultation plus $40 per hour for labor. If a customer's total bill was $290, how many hours of labor were charged?
questions.explanation: Set up the linear equation where <math><mi>h</mi></math> is the number of hours: <math><mn>40</mn><mi>h</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>290</mn></math>. Subtract 50 from both sides: <math><mn>40</mn><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>240</mn></math>. Divide by 40: <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the variable (slope/rate) and the constant (intercept/flat fee) to construct the linear model correctly.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: The system of equations <math><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> and <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math> has no solution. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: A system of linear equations has no solution if the lines are parallel, meaning they have the same slope but different y-intercepts. The ratio of the x-coefficients must equal the ratio of the y-coefficients. <math><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>. Solving for <math><mi>k</mi></math>: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, so <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'no solution' in linear systems, set the slopes (or coefficient ratios) equal: <math><mfrac><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>≠</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></math>.

questions.question: The equation of a circle in the xy-plane is given by <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>. What is the length of the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square for both <math><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>y</mi></math>. For <math><mi>x</mi></math>: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. For <math><mi>y</mi></math>: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Add these constants to the right side: <math><mn>11</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>. The equation becomes <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>. The radius squared is 36, so the radius is <math><msqrt><mn>36</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To complete the square for <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></math>, add <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question: For what positive value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> is the equation <math><mo>|</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math> true?
questions.explanation: First, isolate the absolute value term: <math><mo>|</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. This splits into two cases: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> or <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. For the first case: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math> so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. For the second case: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The question asks for the *positive* value, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that absolute value equations <math><mo>|</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></math> typically yield two solutions: <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></math> and <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>B</mi></math>.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A researcher estimates that 42% of the residents in a city support a new policy, with a margin of error of 3% at a 95% confidence level. Which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion based on this estimate?

options.A: Exactly 42% of residents support the policy.
options.B: We can be 95% confident that the true percentage of supporters is between 39% and 45%.
options.C: The true percentage of supporters is 42% or greater.
options.D: If the study were repeated, 95% of the sample proportions would be exactly 42%.

questions.explanation: A margin of error defines a confidence interval. <math><mn>42</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math> results in an interval of 39% to 45%. The confidence level (95%) describes the likelihood that this method produces an interval containing the true population parameter.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Margin of error creates a range (Estimate - MOE to Estimate + MOE). It does not guarantee exact values.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='350' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='168' y1='50' x2='232' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='50' x2='110' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='195' y='70' font-size='14'>y°</text><text x='240' y='70' font-size='14'>48°</text><text x='205' y='135' font-size='14'>x°</text><path d='M 60 50 L 50 45 L 50 55 Z' fill='black'/><path d='M 60 250 L 50 245 L 50 255 Z' fill='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two horizontal parallel lines are intersected by two transversal lines that cross each other between the parallel lines, forming an 'X' or hourglass shape. The angles inside the top triangle formed by this intersection are labeled: the left interior angle is y°, the right interior angle is 48°, and the angle at the intersection vertex is x°.
questions.question: In the figure, two parallel lines are intersected by two transversals that intersect each other between the parallel lines. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>72</mn></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The two transversals and the top parallel line form a triangle. The angles of this triangle are the interior angles at the parallel line, which are <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>48</mn><mo>°</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, and the vertical angle at the intersection, which is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo></math>. Since the sum of the angles in any triangle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, we have the equation: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>48</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Substituting the given value <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>72</mn></math>: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>72</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>48</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Combining terms: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Solving for x: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='350' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='168' y1='50' x2='232' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='50' x2='110' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='168,50 290,50 200,150' fill='yellow' fill-opacity='0.3' stroke='orange' stroke-width='2'/><text x='185' y='70' font-size='14'>72°</text><text x='250' y='70' font-size='14'>48°</text><text x='195' y='135' font-size='14'>x°</text><text x='230' y='30' font-size='14' fill='orange' font-weight='bold'>Triangle Sum = 180°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart highlights the triangle formed by the top parallel line and the two transversals. The angles 72°, 48°, and x° are shown as the interior angles of this triangle, illustrating the equation x + 72 + 48 = 180.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In 'X' shapes created by transversals between parallel lines, look for the triangles formed. The sum of angles in any triangle is always 180°. [Image of triangle angle sum theorem]

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. The graph of <math><mi>f</mi></math> in the xy-plane is shifted 5 units to the left and 2 units down to obtain the graph of <math><mi>g</mi></math>. Which equation defines <math><mi>g</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The vertex of <math><mi>f</mi></math> is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Shifting 5 units left affects the x-coordinate: <math><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Shifting 2 units down affects the y-coordinate: <math><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. The new vertex is <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. In vertex form <math><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>, this corresponds to <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, or <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To shift a function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> left by <math><mi>c</mi></math> units, replace <math><mi>x</mi></math> with <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. To shift down by <math><mi>d</mi></math>, subtract <math><mi>d</mi></math> from the entire function.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='280' y2='270' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='30' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='270' y='285' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='15' y='30' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>y</text><circle cx='50' cy='265' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='90' cy='260' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='130' cy='245' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='170' cy='215' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='210' cy='160' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='250' cy='70' r='4' fill='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot with the x-axis and y-axis labeled. The points start low and flat near the origin, then rise increasingly steeply as they move to the right, forming a 'J' shape curve characteristic of exponential growth.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>. Which of the following equations is the most appropriate model for the data shown?
questions.explanation:
To determine the best model, analyze the shape of the scatterplot:
1.  **Direction:** As <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> increases, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> increases. This eliminates models representing decay or negative slope (Option B is linear decreasing, Option D is exponential decay because the base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>0.8</mn><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></math>).
2.  **Shape:** The points do not follow a straight line; the rate of increase gets steeper as <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> gets larger. This 'curving upward' behavior is characteristic of exponential growth.
3.  **Conclusion:** Option A is linear growth (constant slope). Option C is exponential growth (base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>1.3</mn><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></math>). The graph fits an exponential growth model.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='280' y2='270' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='30' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 30 270 Q 180 270 250 70' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' fill='none'/><circle cx='50' cy='265' r='4' fill='black' opacity='0.5'/><circle cx='90' cy='260' r='4' fill='black' opacity='0.5'/><circle cx='130' cy='245' r='4' fill='black' opacity='0.5'/><circle cx='170' cy='215' r='4' fill='black' opacity='0.5'/><circle cx='210' cy='160' r='4' fill='black' opacity='0.5'/><circle cx='250' cy='70' r='4' fill='black' opacity='0.5'/><text x='100' y='100' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>Exponential Growth</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The scatterplot is shown with a red curve superimposed over the points. The curve starts flat and swoops upwards, clearly demonstrating the exponential trend described in the explanation.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the shape of the data: straight line = linear; J-curve = exponential. [Image of linear vs exponential growth graph] Check direction: increasing = growth; decreasing = decay.

questions.skill: Absolute value, quadratic, exponential, polynomial, rational, and other nonlinear equations
questions.question: What is the smallest positive integer value of <math><mi>b</mi></math> for which the equation <math><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has two distinct real solutions?
questions.explanation: For a quadratic equation to have two distinct real solutions, the discriminant <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math> must be greater than 0. Here <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. So <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, which simplifies to <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, or <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>></mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Since we are looking for the smallest *positive* integer <math><mi>b</mi></math>, we test squares of integers. <math><msup><mn>7</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, which is not greater than 60. <math><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></math>, which is greater than 60. Therefore, the smallest positive integer value is 8.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Discriminant <math><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>: 2 real roots. Discriminant <math><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: 1 real root. Discriminant <math><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: no real roots.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='60,250 300,250 300,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 280 250 L 280 230 L 300 230' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='50' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='310' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='310' y='145' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='180' y='270' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='310' y='200' font-size='14'>5</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle ABC with the right angle at vertex C. The horizontal leg AC has a length of 12, and the vertical leg BC has a length of 5. Vertex A is at the bottom-left.
questions.question: In the right triangle shown, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation:
1.  **Find the hypotenuse <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>:**
    Using the Pythagorean theorem: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>169</mn></math>.
    So, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.

2.  **Use the co-function identity:**
    The expression <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is equal to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></math>.

3.  **Calculate <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></math>:**
    In a right triangle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>Adjacent</mi><mi>Hypotenuse</mi></mfrac></math>.
    The side adjacent to angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> (length 12), and the hypotenuse is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> (length 13).
    Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>13</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='60,250 300,250 300,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 280 250 L 280 230 L 300 230' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='50' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='310' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='310' y='145' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='180' y='270' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Adjacent = 12</text><text x='310' y='200' font-size='14'>5</text><text x='140' y='190' font-size='14' fill='green' transform='rotate(-22.6 140,190)'>Hypotenuse = 13</text><path d='M 100 250 A 40 40 0 0 1 97 235' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><text x='110' y='245' font-size='14' fill='red'>A</text><text x='310' y='125' font-size='14' fill='purple'>90°- A</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart illustrates the solution. The hypotenuse is labeled as 13. Angle A is highlighted in red, and the adjacent side (12) is highlighted in blue, illustrating the calculation for cos(A). Angle B is labeled as 90°-A, showing that sin(90°-A) is equivalent to looking at the triangle from the perspective of angle B (Opposite/Hypotenuse = 12/13).
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall the co-function identity: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> . This allows you to switch between sine and cosine by looking at the complementary angle.

questions.question: Line <math><mi>p</mi></math> passes through the points <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Line <math><mi>k</mi></math> is perpendicular to line <math><mi>p</mi></math> and passes through the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Line <math><mi>k</mi></math> intersects the x-axis at the point <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: First, find the slope of line <math><mi>p</mi></math>: <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>11</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math> or <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. The slope of perpendicular line <math><mi>k</mi></math> is the negative reciprocal: <math><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. The equation of line <math><mi>k</mi></math> is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math> (since y-intercept is 10). To find the x-intercept, set <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: <math><mn>0</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. <math><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math>. <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Perpendicular lines have slopes that are negative reciprocals (product is -1).
